name: NPR
text:
The presidential election underscored deep divisions in U.S. society.

We want to hear from you: Where does the country go from here? How do you think Americans can move forward as a nation?

Please fill out this form, and we may be in touch for a story.
https://t.co/HloizCAkWG

name: NPR
text:
On the same day that Pfizer announced early good news about its coronavirus vaccine, its CEO sold $5.6 million worth of company stock as its value skyrocketed.

That has raised serious questions about what he knew and when.
 https://t.co/JOTeFAngAn

name: NPR
text:
JUST IN: President-elect Joe Biden has named Ron Klain, a longtime Democratic consultant, as his chief of staff. Klain previously served as President Obama's Ebola czar.
https://t.co/sPomfnU90Q

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Biden has pledged to accept as many as 125,000 refugees a year — after the Trump White House slashed the resettlement program, setting a record-low cap of 15,000.

Here's a look at some of the challenges that await.
https://t.co/Md0UhFz01M

name: NPR
text:
Emily Harrington climbed her way into the history books last week, becoming the first woman to free-climb the Golden Gate route of Yosemite National Park's El Capitan in less than a day.
https://t.co/BTNDvWyQML

name: NPR
text:
Texas has now recorded more than 1 million coronavirus cases, according to Johns Hopkins University data. The state accounts for about 10% of all U.S. cases.
https://t.co/3sqltYdACC

name: NPR
text:
Census data suggest a larger number of men are spending more time at home. One dad gets emotional thinking about how much he's missed — and how much he's experiencing now working from home.

"Even with all the chaos, this has been a bonus year for me." https://t.co/fThXqw5lsI

name: NPR
text:
For five decades, NorthPoint Health & Wellness Center in Minneapolis has confronted the ways that racial disparities can hurt its patients' health. 

Community leaders say it's a model for cities facing similar struggles.
https://t.co/RG817aXI47

name: NPR
text:
Nearly 1 in 5 patients diagnosed with COVID-19 is diagnosed with a psychiatric disorder within 3 months, a new study finds. The relationship is bidirectional:

People with psychiatric diagnoses were about 65% more likely to be diagnosed with COVID-19. https://t.co/x6TMLdGOx3

name: NPR
text:
Joseph Robertson was an Army infantryman, and fought at the Battle of the Bulge, the largest and bloodiest battle fought by the U.S. during World War II. 

He told @StoryCorps about a memory from the battle that haunted him for the rest of his life. https://t.co/vacwBQbTO0

name: NPR
text:
The U.S., U.K., E.U., Canada, and Japan have already claimed over 80% of Pfizer's coronavirus vaccine supply for 2021.

That means it likely won't be available to folks in poorer countries, "at least, by the end of next year," a global health expert says. 
https://t.co/CyIbVYA4mG

name: NPR
text: The brand new National Museum Of The U.S. Army has some amazing artifacts, but the star of the show is the focus on individual soldier stories and the stunning visual representation of the Army's role in life and war — the good, bad, and ugly. @wamu885 https://t.co/uOCJTYAQVZ

name: NPR
text:
In this special quarantine Tiny Desk concert, watch award-winning pianist Tigran Hamasyan perform three songs from his home in Armenia.
https://t.co/NK7xW41Ezo

name: NPR
text:
Several YouTube accounts live-streamed fake election results to huge audiences on Election Day.

One came from a public YouTube channel with over 650,000 followers and was one of Google's Top 5 results for vote tallies in swing states on Tuesday night.
https://t.co/wjOZsYvPIh

name: NPR
text:
"We framed this virus and compared it to monsters that have plagued our people, in our creation stories, our traditional stories. The Navajo people have fought monsters throughout time," the Navajo Nation president said.
https://t.co/ysbznYpeDZ
